name: MyBitcoin
description: Because of the weak password storage system at Mt. Gox, users who used same password for both MyBitcoin and Mt. Gox were infiltrated and significant amounts of assets were lost there too. By MyBitcoin's estimation about 1% of all users were affected by the security breach/ incident/ illegal hack.

name: Ubitex
description: After the raising around 1,100 bitcoins on the now defunct Global Bitcoin Stock Exchange, the founder of the Ubitex service disappeared with all of the cryptocurrency.

name: Bitomat
description: The entire database of the crypto exchange Bitomat became inaccessible because of the loss of wallet.dat file. The exchange stored all their information, eg. wallet files, on a virtual machine on the cloud until the settings were changed by an unknown infiltrator.

name: MyBitcoin
description: There isn't a lot of information about the MyBitcoin breach. Many say that the founder of MyBitcoin, Tom Williams, ran the supposed infiltration as a scam. All evidence has been inconclusive. As a result, one of most successful bitcoin companies of that time was closed.

name: Moonco.in
description: While bitcoin was poorly performing in 2011, alternative cryptocurrencies boomed. The Moonco.in exchange tried to gain the maximum possible from this boom and then, suddenly, Mr. Moon disappeared with all the collected money.

name: Bitcoin7
description: Eastern European cyber-terrorists attacked cryptocurrency exchange Bitcoin7 and gained access to two of three of their backup wallets and main bitcoin depository. It's possible that the culprits still hold the Bitcoin7 domain, as it now offers a scammy bitcoin-doubler service.

name: Mt. Gox
description: 2,609 bitcoins from Mt. Gox were destroyed by the initializing of dozens of transactions that sent large amounts of bitcoin to invalid scripts.

name: Linode
description: As a result of the infiltration of web hosting provider Linode, two exchanges - Slush and Bitcoinica - were robbed of 46,000 BTC in total.

name: Bitscalper
description: Initially presented as a successful investment project, Bitscalper invited users to invest their hard-earned money. High and profitable returns were promised. However, it was planned as scam from the beginning. Bitscalper subsequently shut down and never returned any of the funds.

name: Betcoin
description: The attacker compromised three Betcoin computers and stole all of the deposits and cold wallet funds amounting to 3,171 BTC. Just a small part of the stolen coins was refunded to the users.

name: BitCoinica
description: A suspicious bitcoin transaction was discovered by BitCoinica that wasn't initiated by anyone from company, and the withdrawal was almost 19,000 BTC. The company suspended operations to focus on the investigation. Users were refunded 50% of their deposits.

name: Bitcoin Savings and Trust
description: Starting as First Pirate Savings and Trust, and later becoming Bitcoin Savings and Trust (BST), the operation was a Ponzi scheme driven by Trendon Shavers. Attempts to reduce interest rates caused mass withdrawals. After that, BST was closed and rthe eturn of funds was announced. It refunded money to eleven users and BST announced default.

name: Bitcoin Syndicate
description: The Bitcoin Syndicate account on Mt. Gox exchange was breached, and the attacker sold off the USD and withdrew all assets.

name: BitCoinica
description: BitCoinica hadn't changed all of their passwords after the previous hack two months before, and the attacker was able to steal 40,000 BTC and 40,000 USD.

name: BTC-e
description: The cyber-terrorist imitated deposits on several accounts using a stolen API secret key and then bought and withdrew BTC, LTC and Namecoin.

name: kronos.io
description: There was a vulnerability in the withdrawal script left by one of the website creators. He then used the vulnerability to steal the majority of the kronos.io funds.

name: BitFloor
description: The attacker compromised a few BitFloor servers and retrieved backups for the wallet keys. The culprit used the stolen keys to withdraw the majority of BitFloor's assets.

name: Cdecker
description: A long-time bitcoin user, Cdecker, suddenly found that his personal bitcoin wallet had been emptied.

name: 50BTC
description: The 50BTC billing had an unidentified vulnerability that allowed the attacker to withdraw the bitcoin. The software was completely rewritten after incident.

name: Trojan Wallet
description: Using a trojan horse, a cyber-terrorist stole thousands of bitcoin between September and November 2012. The biggest individual loss was about 2,600 BTC.

name: BitMarket.eu
description: Bitmarket exchange lost 18,787 BTC in 2012 as a result of the incident at BitCoinica before it. All Bitmarket funds kept on the BitCoinica account were lost.

name: Bit LC Inc.
description: One of the major Bit LC Inc. company shareholders disappeared with a huge amount of user assets. He was a holder of the Bit LC Inc. cold wallet that allowed him to withdraw funds without any problems. After this incident Bit LC Inc. announced its closing.

name: BTC Guild
description: Because of a bug in a new version of the software used by BTC Guild, 16 independent thieves were able to steal all assets from the mining pool's hot wallet.

name: Bitcoin Rain
description: The majority of Bitcoin Rain's funds were stolen from its balance on the Marcado Bitcoin exchange. Bitcoin Rain subsequently announced that it defaulted. However, many users wrote that Bitcoin Rain owner Leandro CŽsar had in fact committed an exit scam.

name: ZigGap
description: ZigGap was founded as a small exchange by a bitcoin user who had experience in such kind of ventures. However, it appeared that the founder had some form of mental illness and they shut down the service, taking all of the deposited assets with them.

name: OzCoin
description: The attacker gained access to the OzCoin exchange server where he withdrew money from an exchange wallet and then defaced the website and its database.

name: Bitmit
description: The server of a Bitmit auction was accessed by an insider and 15 bitcoins were stolen. The insider turned out to be an employee of the hosting company.

name: PicoStocks
description: Picostocks suffered a theft of funds when 1,300 BTC were stolen.

name: Bitfunder and WeExchange
description: The software of Bitfunder and WeExchange platforms were breached, and the attacker was able to steal 6,000 BTC of exchange funds.

name: Just-Dice
description: Because of a Just-Dice operator mistake, a client was able to withdraw 1,300 BTC without having his balance change. The user continued betting using the fake balance; however, he didn't get any wins.

name: BASIC-MINING
description: Taking advantage of the mining boom, the BASIC-MINING founder disappeared after the collapse of BTC-TC - exchange on which BASIC-MINING was traded. The founder took almost all of the client assets with them.

name: inputs.io
description: Due to a successful social engineering attack, the culprit compromised the email accounts of some employees and withdrew 4,100 BTC total.

name: GBL
description: With a powerful advertising campaign, the crypto exchange GBL attracted user assets and then shut down, taking significant amount of funds with them.

name: Bitcash.cz
description: The server of Bitcash.cz was compromised and attacked, and an exchange wallet with 4,000 BTC was emptied.

name: BIPS
description: Hit with a DDoS attack, the payment processor was attacked, and best part of the 1,295 BTC stolen was owned by company itself with several client wallets were compromised also.

name: PicoStocks
description: An ex-employee of PicoStocks with access to keys stole funds from both hot and cold wallets. However, almost 6,000 BTC was covered by the exchange completely, and no creditor was affected.

name: Mt. Gox
description: It was claimed that the platform became insolvent as a result of about 850,000 BTC that were stolen over the years due to a bug. allowing for the making of fake transactions over time. Mt Gox became bankrupt and shut down permanently.

name: Flexcoin
description: Almost all funds held on the exchange's hot wallet were stolen. With a total amount of 896 BTC stolen, no creditor was ever refunded.

name: Poloniex
description: Using a vulnerability in the exchange code, the culprit simultaneously requested a number of successful withdrawals despite their being an insufficient balance. All 97 BTC that were stolen were refunded to clients.

name: Cryptorush
description: By inflating the amount available on its account, a cyber-terrorist was then able to withdraw the coins from the exchange.

name: Bitcurex
description: The attack on Bitcurex was blocked by automatic safety procedures, preventing a significant theft of user BTC assets. However, the criminal did manage to steal a portion of cryptocurrency from one of the exchange's hot wallets.

name: DogeVault
description: The Dogecoin storage provider was compromised by an attacker and 111m DOGE were lost in the incident.

name: MintPal
description: Exploiting a vulnerability in the exchange withdrawal system, the attacker was able to steal VRC, BTC and LTC from wallets. VRC developers helped MintPal to get the coins back.

name: Cryptsy
description: There was a backdoor inside of the exchange wallet code and, sometime later, a new developer used this backdoor to steal BTC and LTC.

name: Bter
description: Due to an attack on the exchange hosting servers, the culprit stole 50m NXT. A last block rollback was discussed as a possible solution, however the exchange refunded all lost assets through its own efforts.

name: Bitpay
description: Using the spear phishing technique, the attacker got access to the exchange CFO's e-mail account. Through this access, the thief was able to steal about 5,000 BTC.

name: MintPal
description: After the previous security breach at MintPal, the exchange was bought by Alex Green who announced that MintPal had become insolvent due to a bug in the software. MintPal user accounts were blocked and the funds were transferred to (it's presumed) Green's wallet. Green has not been heard from since.

name: Bitstamp
description: Using social engineering, the cyber-terrorist gained access to two servers containing the wallet.dat file and passphrase for the exchange's hot wallet. Bitstamp lost about 19,000 BTC from its wallet. No information about refunding was ever provided.

name: EgoPay
description: Using a breach in the payment processor system, the attacker was able to make false balances and convert them into other cryptocurrencies within a one-hour window. There is no information what as to exact currency was stolen using this method.

name: LocalBitcoins
description: Using some kind of keylogger software, the culprit made withdrawals from user accounts, stealing 17 BTC in total. The effect was fairly low due to the quick reaction of the exchange and its users.

name: 796.com
description: Through compromised exchange software, the attacker was able to change other user withdrawal addresses. Using this breach, they stole 1,000 BTC. 796.com handled this quickly and no more clients were affected.

name: MyCoin
description: Founded as a Ponzi scheme from the beginning, MyCoin never operated a bitcoin exchange business at all. The exchange then shut down, taking the funds of all 3,000 clients with it.

name: exco.in
description: The cyber-terrorist performed an attack using a DDoS attack and gained access to an exchange wallet. The thief then stole about 2,000 BTC.

name: Bter
description: The exchange platform was shut down due to a cold wallet being compromised. The criminal was able to steal 7,170 BTC in total.

name: KipCoin
description: A attacker retrieved a wallet.dat file from KipCoin's server, then waited for a couple of months to use it, and withdrew about 3,000 BTC.

name: Bitfinex
description: Through a compromised Bitfinex hot wallet, the culprit was able to steal a small part of exchange funds - 1,400 BTC. The platform announced that its customer accounts wouldn't be affected and the lost assets would be covered by the exchange's own funds.

name: Purse
description: Using phishing malware, the attacker was able to gain access to the platform user accounts and could withdraw their assets. The total amount of lost funds was 10,235 BTC.

name: Shapeshift
description: An employee at Shapeshift sold sensitive security information to a cyber-terrorist. Both the attacker and the employee stole about 469 BTC, 1,900 LTC and 5,800 ETH. The platform was able to recover a significant amount of the lost assets.

name: Gatecoin.com
description: As a result of a cyberattack on Gatecoin hot wallets, the culprit was able to steal 250 BTC and 185,000 ETH.

name: DAO
description: A software vulnerability in the DAO allowed a cyber-terrorist to steal a huge portion of ETH currency - 3,600,000 in total. However, the system hard fork was applied and those assets were returned back to the system.

name: Bitfinex
description: Because of a vulnerability in the Bitfinex accounts structure, an attacker was able to gain access to the platform wallets where they stole 119,756 BTC.

name: Bitcurex
description: Bitcurex announced that platform had suffered a cyber-attack and lost over 2,300 BTC. The exchange said it would be able to restart its operations and refund its customers.

name: Yapizon.com
description: The crypto exchange announced that it has become the victim of cyber-attackers. The attacker stole 37% of Yapizon holdings that amounted 3,800 BTC.

name: Bithumb
description: Using the employee's home PC as main tool for the hack, the thief was able to gain account authentication codes and withdrew those assets. There was no further information whether victims would be compensated or not.

name: CoinDash
description: The cyber-terrorist changed the CoinDash ICO wallet address on the official website and collected about 43,500 ETH. The culprit then returned a part of the stolen amount and the rest was compensated with CoinDash tokens.

name: Parity
description: Using a vulnerability in the Parity smart contracts, the attacker stole 150,000 ETH.

name: BTC-e
description: A ransomware attack on BTC-e allowed the cashout of 66,000 BTC. However, it is possible that the BTC-e founder executed an exit scam running from a number of warrants.

name: Enigma
description: By gaining access to the CEO's emails, the platform website, and a number of social accounts, the thief was ableo to create a fake presale and collected 1,492 ETH in total.

name: Control Finance
description: A scam from the beginning, Control-Finance claimed to pay daily trading profits of 1.5%. Customers saw fake balances and were receiving reports with false data. The director disappeared with all of the customer funds amounting to 22,900 BTC.

name: Coinis
description: The Coinis hot wallet was breached and about 508 BTC were withdrawn in total.

name: OKEx
description: A couple of OKEx users reported that their accounts had been accessed by a cyber-terrorist. The thief sold all of the BTC on the balance and cancelled all the orders. As a result, about 600 BTC were stolen in total.

name: Parity
description: There was no illicit activity in this incident, instead a user accidentally used a contract vulnerability and managed to lock approximately 513,000 ETH.

name: Tether
description: Malicious actions by an unknown attacker allowed them to send 30,950,000 USDT to an unknown bitcoin address. The assets were subsequently returned using Omni Layer protocol enhancements.

name: NiceHash
description: Using a security breach on the website, the culprit was able to compromise the NiceHash payment system, and stole 4,376 BTC from their wallet. Almost all of the funds were repaid to the customers.

name: Youbit
description: The platform filed itself as bankrupt after it had a securuty breach. A cyber-attack on the exchange had allowed the attacker to steal 17% of its holdings. Youbit clients were compensated as much as 75% of their loss.

name: EtherDelta
description: The cyber-terrorist made a mirror website of EtherDelta by hijacking its DNS server and redirected all official website traffic. The scam website managed to collect 308 ETH and a couple of ERC-20 tokens.

name: BlackWallet
description: The thief compromised the platform hosting server and changed the settings so as to withdraw all customer balances to his own address. As a result, almost 670,000 XLM were stolen in the incident.

name: Coincheck
description: This was the one of the biggest crypto security breaches in history. The Coincheck system was breached in unannounced manner and 500,000,000 of NEM tokens were stolen. The exchange considered compensation for clients, but there has been no more information about this.

name: BitGrail
description: As was reported, the exchange held all Nano tokens in a single hot wallet, which was the wallet that was compromised and emptied. The total amount of stolen coins was 17,000,000 Nano. There was suspicious behaviour by the BitGrail founder Francesco Firano, and as a result he was sentenced to return as much of the funds as possible.

name: Blockchain.info
description: A Blockchain.info website duplicate was created and advertised everywhere. This website turned out to be a malicious phishing scam set up to steal cryptocurrency assets from user wallets.

name: Coinsecure
description: Coinsecure noticed a security breach during which an attacker took control of over 438 BTC.

name: MyEtherWallet
description: The culprit gained entry to MyEtherWallet servers and managed to gain partial control of its ETH funds.

name: TAYLOR
description: Cyber-terrorists gained access to the TAYLOR wallets and managed to get control of over 2500 ETH, and a significant amount of TAY tokens.

name: Coinrail
description: The exchange experienced a breach in its security system with a loss of 30 percent of its cryptocurrency reserves.

name: Bithumb
description: Bithumb's hot wallet was breached and the thief managed to withdraw ETH and XRP, amongst other digital assets, from the exchange.

name: Bancor
description: Due to a security breach, Bancor lost over 3.2m Bancor tokens, 25.000 ETH, and 230m NPXS tokens.

name: kickico.co
description: Kickico acknowledged a security breach during which an attacker took control of over 70m KICK tokens that were in the platform's wallets.

name: ZAIF
description: The culprit attacked Zaif hot wallets and managed to steal BTC, BCH and MONA coins. Zaif only detected the security breach several days after the hack had happened.

name: Trade.io
description: The Trade.io cold wallet was compromised and the exchange lost over 50 million Tio Tokens.

name: MapleChange
description: MapleExchange claimed that it lost all of its funds to criminals and decided to shut down its operations. However, the weird behaviour caused social media users to think that it possibly could have been another exit scam attempt.

name: Electrum
description: The hack on an Electrum cryptocurrency wallet caused a loss of almost 250 BTC. According to an Electrum announcement, the malicious attack included the creation of a fake version of the wallet that asked users to provide their password information.

name: Cryptopia
description: Cryptopia experienced a security breach which led to significant losses of digital funds.

name: LocalBitcoins
description: LocalBitcoin became the victim of a security breach when the attackers managed to change the official link to the forum with a fake one. As a result, they took the confidential information of customers who tried to log in through this link.

name: QuadrigaCX
currency: BCH, BCH(SV),  BTC,  BTG,  ETH,  LTC
description: The official version is that due to the death of the founder, QuadrigaCX lost its private keys to its cold wallets and therefore could not manage to return any funds to its customers.

name: Coinbin
description: Coinbin shut down and closed all operations as a result of a significant debt growth, caused by embezzlement by a senior executive.

name: DragonEx
description: A cyber-terrorist attacked the DragonEx wallet, resulting in a loss of user and platform funding. In addition to the main wallet, the DragonEx exchange deposit wallet was also compromised, it was attacked by methods other than the "Fake Deposit" scheme. It's thought that the attacker could have compromised the exchange's servers and then obtained the private keys of the hot wallet and deposit wallet.

name: Etbox
description: The Etbox security system was compromised, hence the exchange's digital assets were stolen.

name: BiKi
description: Biki underwent a verification code attack and some user accounts and passwords were tampered with.

name: CoinBene
description: CoinBene experienced a security breach and as result lost over $45m.

name: Bithumb
description: Due to an insider attack, Bithumb's EOS and XRP hot wallets were compromised and the exchange lost its funds.

name: BitoPro
description: The culprit used a partial payment feature to fake deposits and managed to take over 7m XRP from the exchange.

name: Binance
description: Binance experienced a major security breach, and as a result the attacker managed to withdraw over 7000 BTC from its hot wallet.

name: Coinbase
description: A Coinbase client lost all funds from their account through a SIM port hack.

name: Kraken
description: The illegal hacker took advantage of the exchange's order book by creating a number of orders to purchase BTC against CAD at extremely low prices and then pulled BTC to the open market to trigger their buy orders on their other account.

name: Coinroom
description: Coinroom shut down all operations and left the market with the customers' money.

name: GateHub
description: Cyber-terrorists reportedly took control of nearly 100 XRP Ledger wallets on the cryptocurrency wallet service GateHub.

name: TokenStore
description: TokenStore exit scammed the market, leaving with various mainstream currencies such as BTC, ETH, XRP, etc.

name: Bitsane
description: Bitsane vanished from the market with their all clients' funds.

name: Bitrue
description: After a massive security breach, Bitrue lost 9.3 million XRP and 2.5m Cardano (ADA) from its hot wallet.

name: BitcoinsNorway
description: Bitcoin Norway shut down after cyber-terrorists gained access to the platform via a SIM swap attack.

name: Soxex
description: Soxex exchange owners ran with over $1m in USDT.

name: BitMarket.pl
description: BitMarket.pl shut down among exit scam claims, without giving any prior notice to its clients.

name: Bitpoint
description: Bitpoint noticed an error in its outgoing operations and after a short period of time revealed that they had lost a significant amount of funds due to a security breach.

name: CoinTiger
description: During a regular cold wallet verification check, it was identified that a PTT cold wallet had been compromised.

name: VinDAX
description: The culprits transferred around 23 different coins from the exchange's hot wallets.

name: Upbit
description: The hot wallets of the Korean exchange were compromised by attackers, and this led to the loss of 342,000 ETH.

name: Plus Token Ponzi
description: Plus Token was a cryptocurrency Ponzi scheme disguised as a high-yield investment program. The owners abandoned their users by withdrawing over $2.9b in crypto.

name: Electrum
description: Bad actors provided a malicious version of an Electrum wallet in order to get access to the funds of clients, who then provided their confidential data.

name: Altsbit
description: The Italian exchange, Altbit kept the majority of funds in its hot wallets, which were compromised by criminals.

name: IOTA wallet
description: Cyber-terrorists exploited the vulnerability of the official IOTA application and gained access to millions of MIOTA tokens.

name: Ledger
description: The attackers created a malicious Ledger extension for Google Chrome and stole over 1.4 million XRP.

name: Bisq
description: A criminal exploited a security vulnerability in the trading protocol, and as a result managed to change the address which collected funds from failed trades.

name: Uniswap
description: The culprit abused a known vulnerability in ERC-777 tokens and gained access to exchange funds.

name: dForce (Lendf.me)
description: Due to a vulnerability with ERC777, the attackers managed to gain control over imBTC tokens.

name: Wotoken
currency: BCH, BTC,  EOS,  ETH,  LTC,  OTHER
description: This scam was in operation between July 2018 and October 2019. Over 715,000 users were scammed by Wotoken which stole approximately 46,000 BTC, more than 2 million ETH, 292,000 LTC, 56,000 BCH, 684,000 EOS, and several other smaller cryptocurrencies.

name: Balancer
description: The cyber-terrorist used a billionth of a token to swap for other assets on the platform. Due to the burn mechanism, the tokens were never actually exchanged, which allowed the culprit to perform the transfer multiple times until all pools were dried.

name: Cashaa
description: The malware was installed onto an employee's personal computer, which was linked to an exchange. As a result, Cashaa was breached and lost approximately 336 BTC.

name: Twitter
description: Cyber-terrorists gained access to dozens of verified Twitter accounts and launched a fake donation campaign, during which assailants managed to gain over 13 BTC.

name: 2gether
description: Criminals broke into the servers of a Spanish cryptocurrency exchange 2gether and stole over a quarter (28%) from the companyÕs funds.

name: Opyn
description: DeFi risk-management platform Opyn was hacked via a “double-exercise” attack and lost its funds.

name: Electrum
description: A user of an Electrum wallet installed an old version of the wallet which consisted of a malicious code. After installing the update, the whole balance was then transferred to the attacker.

name: Chainlink
description: At least nine Chainlink node operators were attacked which caused a loss of around 700 ETH. The attack presumably abused the way the nodes responded to queries and used tokens related to the cost of network transactions.

name: ETERBASE
currency: ALGO, BTC,  ETH,  TRX,  XRP,  XTZ
description: ETERBASE announced that cyber-terrorists had breached its internal network and stole cryptocurrency funds from its 6 hot wallets. In a series of messages posted on its Telegram channel, the company said it detected the attack but could not stop it from taking place.

name: bZx
description: bZx lost tokens due to a code mistake in the contract.

name: Kucoin
description: KuCoin representatives explained they had discovered that the attackers managed to use a security breach and gained access to the exchange's hot wallets, from which ERC-20 tokens mainly were stolen, but some amounts of BTC and ETH were lost too. The platform plans to cover all lost user funds completely.

name: Eminence
description: Unaudited platform Eminence was hacked even before its official launch.

name: Ledger
description: The Ledger wallet owners began to receive fake emails about a security breach in the software. Users were asked to update their wallet, but this was actually phishing software. About 107 BTС and 1,150,000 XRP were stolen.

name: Harvest Finance
description: An attacker executed a theft of funds from the USDC and USDT vaults of Harvest Finance. The attacker exploited an arbitrage and impermanent loss that influences the value of individual assets inside the Y pool of Curve.fi, which is where the funds of Harvest’s vaults were invested.

name: Value
description: Value lost a large amount of funds as a result of a flash loan exploit.

name: Cheese Bank
description: Criminals managed to drain the digital assets from Cheese Bank by exploiting a bug in the system.

name: OUSD
description: A bad actor gained control of OUSD funds.

name: Pickle Finance
description: Pickle lost over a half of its tokens due to a security breach.

name: Maker
description: Maker lost control if its funds due to a spam and server attack.

name: Akropolis
description: Cyber terrorists gained control of Akropolis funds via a security breach.

name: Warp Finance
description: Warp Finance suffered a major system attack and lost a significant amount of funds.

name: EXMO
currency: BTC, ETC,  ETH,  USDT,  XRP,  ZEC
description: On December 21, 2020, EXMO hot wallets were compromised via a security breach. The amounts of BTC, ETH, XRP and some other cryptocurrencies were stolen.

name: Attily
description: Attily exchange lost its funds due to an attack on its servers.

name: Cover Protocol
description: Cover protocol experienced a security breach and lost a significant amount of digital asset funds.

name: Cryptopia
description: Cryptopia lost a small amount of funds, but the reasons are yet unknown.

name: Yearn Finance
description: The criminal managed to drain digital assets from an exploit of the Yearn DAI vault.

name: Alpha Homora
description: Alpha Homora lost over $35M in a hackers attack

name: Furucombo
description: An exploiter used a fake contract to trick the app into thinking it was a typical update.

name: Meerkat Finance
description: $31 million worth of crypto assets were stolen from the wallets of Meerkat Finance

name: DODO
description: The attacker exploited a bug in the pools' smart contract in order to steal funds from DODO exchange.

name: Turtle.dex
description: Turtle.dex made an exit scam with 9,000 BNB of user funds.

name: Polkatrain
description: Polkatrain suffered a rebate arbitrage attack resulting in the loss of $3 million.

name: EasyFi
description: The thief gained access to the private keys belonging to the project’s admin account and managed to withdraw over $80m worth of coins.

name: Thodex
description: Thodex shut down its site and the founder reportedly fled the country with as much as $2 billion (€1.7 billion) in investors' assets.

name: Uranium Finance
description: Uranium Finance lost $50 million in tokens in an exploit.

name: Spartan Protocol
description: Spartan Protocol was exploited due to “a flawed liquidity share calculation” in the protocol, resulting in a loss of more than $30 million.

name: Value
description: The exploiter took control of the pool and drained the original stake token.

name: Value
description: Hackers again gained control of the pool and drained tokens.

name: Rari Capital
description: The hacker had exploited Rari’s yield-generating strategy by essentially manipulating the value of ETH and then withdrawing more ETH from Rari’s pool before anyone caught on.

name: X Token
description: The attack was carried out using two exploits, both targeting tokens in the protocols ecosystem.

name: Bearn.Fi
description: The attacker exploited the BearnFi BvaultsBank smart contract, draining the $11 million that was in the pool.

name: PancakeBunny
description: For his price manipulation, the hacker managed to arrange 7 instant loans from PancakeSwap pools.

name: DeFi100
description: Defi100 rug pulled its customers and has stolen over $32M

name: AutoShark
description: The hacker used the breach in the protocol and managed to withdraw over $750,000.

name: MerlinLabs
description: A fork of PancakeBunny was hacked and the platform lost about 240 ETH which was worth about $680,000 at the time it was hacked.

name: MerlinLabs
description: The second attack took advantage of a mistake in their new price function and helped hackers to withdraw another portion of funds from Merlin.

name: BurgerSwap
description: The Burgerswap project explained that the project saw $7.2 million in funds drained after a malicious flash loan attack.

name: Belt
description: Another flash loan exploit helped the hacker to get out with DeFi funds.

name: Alchemist
description: Due to a bug, users were able to withdraw their ETH collateral with their alETH loans still outstanding — a rugpull by the community to the tune of $6.5 million.

name: Eleven Finance
description: Eleven Finance suffered flash loan attacks, resulting in 100% of deposited funds lost.

name: StableMagnet
description: The BSC on-chain project StableMagnet ran away with $27m in an exit scam.

name: SafeDollar
description: Due to a cyberattack a DeFi stablecoin lost its funds.

name: MerlinLabs
description: Hackers again attacked the protocol and stole the remaining funds.

name: AnySwap
description: The attacker drained AnySwap liquidity pools after the use of a security breach in protocols.

name: ChainSwap
description: The hacker found a security breach in the contract and managed to withdraw ChainSwap funds.

name: Bondly
description: An unknown attacker took advantage of the infinite mint bug and dumped the 373m “created out of thin air” BONDLY tokens.

name: ThorChain
description: THORChain network experienced an attack and the protocol suffered from a hack, in which the perpetrator is estimated to have made off with ~$6 million in crypto assets.

name: PancakeBunny
description: Hackers managed to drain digital assets from an exploit in the protocol.

name: Array Finance
description: Array was hit with a flash loan attack. The attacker borrowed a flash loan and managed to withdraw ETH.

name: Sanshu Inu
description: Due to a Sanshu Inu hack, the attacker was able to generate a profit of almost 56 ETH.

name: ThorChain
description: THORChain was hacked for $8 million for the second time. As a result of the hack, many ERC-20 tokens have lost value.

name: PolyYeld Finance
description: After attackers used a vulnerability to generate roughly 4.9 trillion tokens, PolyYeld Finance's YELD currency plummeted to zero. On the day of the hack, they sold a chunk of them for ETH, which was valued around $250,000.

name: Levyathan Finance
description: On July 30, 2021, Levyathan was attacked, resulting in the minting of billions of LEV tokens and a price decrease to almost 0.

name: Stazie
description: On CryptoPunk's Discord service, a scammer known as "cryptopunksbot" offered NFT investors the chance to win one of 10 elusive NFT avatars. Stazie, a co-founder of the NFT gaming project Hedgie, took the fake offer posting, but it cost him 16 CryptoPunks, which might be valued at more than $1 million. Stazie accidentally emailed the scammer the wallet seed phrase, resulting in the loss of several ETH.

name: Popsicle Finance
description: Illegal hackers were able to drain one of the DeFi protocol's core products for around $25 million thanks to a weakness in Popsicle Finance.

name: Wault Finance
description: Wault Finance, the BSC chain's DeFi protocol, was attacked by lightning loans on August 4, 2021 and its value plummeted by roughly half.

name: Zerogoki
description: Zerogoki was attacked due to a compromised price oracle.

name: PolyNetwork
description: PolyNetwork, a cross-chain interoperability technology, stated that they had been hacked on the Ethereum, Polygon, and Binance Smart Chains and had lost over $613 million as a result of the theft. The thief has returned the majority of the monies to the team thanks to the efforts of all parties involved.

name: Punk Protocol
description: Punk Protocol was exploited which resulted in more than $8.9 million loss.

name: DAO Maker
description: DAO Maker was hacked in the early hours of August 12, 2021, and one of their wallets with admin rights was compromised.

name: Neko Network
description: The attacker took advantage of a flaw in the Neko Network's MainPool smart contract to mortgage assets in the names of other Neko Network members. The attacker returned $3.8 million of the stolen assets after the incident, removing the threat to all but one of the victims.

name: Ref Finance
description: Due to the patch of a newly released contract, Ref Finance, a set of protocols driven by smart contracts on the NEAR blockchain, was compromised.

name: Fetch.ai
description: Fetch.ai’s account on Binance was hacked and a sum of $2.6 million was wrongfully traded by an unidentified hacker.

name: XSURGE
description: XSurge acknowledged a $5 million hacking vulnerability and has promised to compensate victims.

name: Liquid
description: The online hot wallets of Liquid Global, a legal Japanese cryptocurrency exchange, were hacked for a total of $94 million, including $31 million in Ether, $5 million in Bitcoin, and $13 million in XRP. A total of $45 million in Ethereum blockchain tokens was also taken. Using decentralized peer-to-peer exchanges, the hacker converted a portion of the tokens to Ether money.

name: Finiko
description: Finiko is a Russian Ponzie Scheme that became another scam that drained over $200 million from its users.

name: HitBTC
description: The crypto exchange HitBTC was hacked, according to Sentinel Network, with a total loss of 40 million DVPN tokens, or $1 million, that customers had committed to the platform.

name: Luna Yield
description: Solana-based DeFi Protocol Luna yield reportedly 'rug pulled' investors, and $6.7 Million was taken

name: Dot.Finance
description: DeFi revenue aggregator Dot.Finance suffered a lightning loan attack.

name: Bilaxy
description: A hacking incident was reported by Bilaxy, with cash lost due to an exploit of the platform's ERC-20 hot wallet.

name: X Token
description: xToken was exploited for around $4.5 million following an attack targeting the DeFi protocol’s smart contracts.

name: Cream Finance
description: CreamFinance was attacked via a contract breach.

name: DAO Maker
description: DAO Maker was hacked for a second time and lost over $4 million.

name: Afksystem.finance
description: Afksystem finance rug-pulled all their vaults for a total of $12M

name: Zabu Finance
description: To manufacture tokens, the attacker employed Zabu's "Transfer Tax" mechanism, which set their value to zero.

name: Miso
description: MISO, Sushiswap's token launchpad, was compromised. The hacker made off with 864.8 Ethereum, or $3 million.

name: NowSwap
description: The attacker took advantage of a flaw in the protocol's code to steal $1 million worth of tokens from the project.

name: pNetwork
description: In the second big assault on an Avalanche platform, Vee Finance, a decentralized finance (DeFi) platform, was struck for a $35 million vulnerability.

name: Vee Finance
description: An attacker exploited a flaw in their code to attack pBTC on BSC, taking 277 BTC.

name: Auto Shark Finance
description: AutoShark Finance, a DeFi protocol on Binance Smart Chain fell victim to flash-loan attacks.

name: Evolved Apes
description: Evolved Apes' NFT investors scammed for over $3 million. The anonymous developer vanished, along with the NFT website and the Twitter page.

name: Indexed Finance
description: Two fund pools were impacted by an assault on Indexed Finance, a passive income DeFi platform. The manner of attack is yet unknown, but the overall loss is estimated to be approximately $16 million.

name: CryptoRoom
description: Pyramid-scheme scammers are making use of Apple's Enterprise Developer Program to download phony trading applications onto their victims' iPhones.

name: PancakeHunny
description: Pancake Binance Smart Chain DeFi protocol Hunny was the victim of a flash loan attack.

name: Glide Finance
description: Glide Finance stated that it has been the victim of a hack. The project verified that the exploit was caused by internal process flaws rather than a blockchain vulnerability in a statement explaining the loss of cash.

name: Cream Finance
description: Hackers stole an estimated $130 million worth of cryptocurrency assets from Cream Finance.

name: BXH
description: BXH suffered an exploit, with BXH stating that private keys were compromised.

name: AnubisDAO
description: The AnubisDAO rug pulled in almost 13,200 ETH from its participants. This amounts to nearly $60 million.

name: SQUID
description: The Squidgame Token rug was pulled and took over $17 million.

name: Vesper Finance
description: The attacker constructed a Uniswap liquidity pool on VUSD, a low-liquidity stablecoin project in beta, as part of an oracle manipulation assault against Vesper Finance, a DeFi ecosystem for crypto.

name: bZx
description: The bZx lending protocol was hacked for $55 million. Earlier in the day, the private key managing the project's deployment on Polygon and Binance Smart Chain had been hacked.

name: MonoX.finance
description: Around $31 million in a variety of cryptocurrencies was stolen from MonoX in a DeFi hack.

name: Badger DAO
description: Badger DAO lost over $120m in stolen funds after a hack attack.

name: Bitmart
description: Due to a security breach hackers managed to drain $196 million of crypto by stealing a private key that opened two hot wallets.

name: Pizza.Finance
description: The hacker used eCurve's vulnerability to create an endless supply of Tripool tokens, which they could use as collateral to deposit on the platform. The value of the stolen tokens is $5 million.

name: Sorbet Finance
description: The criminal managed to steal over $744k from Sorbet Finance protocol.

name: Vulcan Forged
description: A hacker exploited the platform to obtain the private keys to 96 crypto wallets and grab roughly 4.5 million Vulcan Forged native PYR tokens

name: AscendEX
description: The hacker used the breach in the AscendEX hotwallet and managed to withdraw over $78M

name: WePiggy
description: The crook manipulated the price of CHE assets which led to $400k in losses.

name: Grim Finance
description: An external attacker managed to exploit Grim Finance protocol and steal $30M

name: 8ight Finance
description: 8ight Finance on the Harmony chain was hacked, and $1.75 million was stolen due to the leak of the private key due to google doc

name: VISR
description: A malicious contract drained Visor Finance’s staking contract of millions of VISR tokens and swapped them to ETH via Uniswap

name: Monkey Kingdom
description: Hackers managed to drain over $1.3M from the NFT project Monkey Kingdom on Solana blockchain through a security breach on Discord.

name: MetaDAO
description: Investors in a project called MetaDAO have found themselves victim of a $3.2 million rug pull scam.

name: META
description: On 27th December, some crypto enthusiasts lost about $1 million through investing in a bogus Metamask token

name: MetaSwap
description: MetaSwap founder scammed their founders and has stolen $600k in BNB tokens.

name: SashimiSwap
description: Hacker managed to drain SashimiSwap ETH liquidity pool.

name: Vesper Finance
description: In this exploit, an attacker manipulated an oracle and drained the beta-test lending pool of approx $1m in DAI, ETH, WBTC, and USDC.

name: Tinyman
description: Hackers' attacks have been aimed at several pools and rewarded the thief with $2M.

name: Arbix Finance
description: ArbixFinance scammed its users for $10M due to a rug pull

name: Bored Bunny
description: Investors lose $20.7 million in Bored Bunny NFT promoted by multiple celebrities

name: DaoMetaland
description: Metaland DAO suffered a rug pull, the project suffered a loss of over $280k

name: LCX
description: LCX suffered from a major security breach and lost almost $10M

name: Frosties
description: Investors in a NFT collection called Frosties have been scammed for over $1 million after creators of the digital tokens absconded with their funds

name: Lympo
description: The sports NFT minting platform suffered a hot wallet security breach across several project wallets, losing $18 million worth of LMT

name: IDO
description: Multiple IDOs rugged for a total of over $2.6m in WBNB on BSC.

name: Rari Capital
description: By using price manipulation, the hacker managed to withdraw over $450k.

name: CityDAO
description: CityDAO Discord admin account has been hacked and has stolen around $95k by a fake airdrop.

name: Crypto.com
description: Crypto.com breach, worth up to $33M, has led to the stealing by unauthorized withdrawals.

name: Crypto Burger
description: A malicious individual discovered an exploit that had the contract for BURG token, managed to burn a large part of the tokens in the liquidity pool, thus greatly increasing the price of the token. This individual immediately liquidated the token he had previously acquired, thus stealing $770K from the liquidity pool.

name: Multichain
description: The cross-chain bridge Multichain confirmed that the hacker managed to steal over $1.93M on the ETH blockchain due to the vulnerability.

name: Crosswise
description: An attacker exploited our Masterchef contract and managed to steal over $879k

name: Kingfund Finance
description: Kingfund Finance had a Rug Pull and lost over 300 WBNB

name: Blockverse
description: Unofficial Minecraft NFT game 'Blockverse' disappears with more than $1.2M

name: Solfire
description: The project owner of SolFire Finance stole all the investors’ funds and transferred $10M to the ETH chain via a cross-chain bridge

name: OpenSea
description: A user nicknamed jpegdegenlove has been caught exploiting an OpenSea API vulnerability on the Rarible platform.

name: Mercenary
description: The scam artists behind Mercenary Gold got away with at least $760k

name: InfinityToken
description: InfinityToken has been rugged with more than 1,390 WBNB.

name: Wegrocoin
description: The project Wegrocoin (WEGRO) on BSC suffered a Rug Pull and lost more than 1000 BNB.

name: Qubit
description: The addresses linked to the hack attack have managed to steal $80M in Binance Coin from Qubit's QBridge protocol.

name: Wormhole
description: An attacker exploited a signature verification vulnerability in the Wormhole network to mint 120k Wormhole-wrapped Ether on Solana. These tokens were not backed by Ether deposits on the Ethereum side of the Portal bridge. The attacker then bridged 93,750 of these tokens to Ethereum, withdrawing the unwrapped Ether from the contract.

name: KLAYswap
description: A South Korean DeFi project, KLAYswap stated it was hacked and lost over 2.2 billion won, or about $1.83 million, in the incident.

name: Meter.io
description: Meter.io's cross-chain bridge was hacked, resulting in a loss of around $4.3 million

name: Superfluid
description: The vulnerability allows the attacker to transfer funds from Superfluid user wallets to exchanges on Polygon and exchange them for ETH.

name: Dego
description: Dego Finance, an NFT and DeFi aggregator, announced that it was hacked, and the DEGO liquidity on UniSwap and PancakeSwap has been exhausted.

name: BabyMuskCoin
description: The project BabyMuskCoin in a rugpull has stolen over $660k.

name: IRA Financial
description: Unidentified hackers withdrew $21 million in BTC and $15 million in ETH from IRA Financial Trust’s accounts.

name: Titano Finance
description: DeFi platform Titano Finance suffered a hack. The attackers – alleged to be contractors hired by the crypto project – stole 4828.7 BNB worth over $1.9 million.

name: Build Finance
description: The Build Finance DAO has been the target of a hostile governance takeover in which a malicious actor has put forward and succeeded with a proposal to take control of the Build token contract

name: TopGoal
description: TopGoal operational wallet has been attacked and compromised.

name: Gold Mine Finance
description: Gold Mine Finance scammed their investors via rug pull.

name: OpenSea
description: The new migration contract launched by OpenSea yesterday was suspected of having a bug, and the attacker used the bug to steal a large amount of NFTs, most of which have been deposited in TornadoCash. Hackers return most of the unsold NFTs to victims.

name: Flurry Finance
description: Flurry Finance’s Vault contract was hit by a flash loan attack, resulting in the theft of approximately $293,000 worth of assets in the Vault contract.

name: Pirate X
description: The staking contract of Pirate X has been attacked and lost around $72k

name: Fantasm Finance
description: Fantom-based algorithmic assets protocol Fantasm Finance was exploited for over $2.6 million worth of crypto.

name: Paraluni
description: The metaverse financial project Paraluni on the BSC chain was hacked, and the hackers made more than $1.7 million in profits.

name: NFTflow
description: NFTFlow rug pulled its customers and disappeared with $230k

name: Agave
description: Agave was drained of all of its liquidity in the amount of $5.5M

name: Deus Finance
description: Deus Finance was exploited in, leading to the gain of $3M for the hacker

name: Hundred Finance
description: Hundred was drained of all of its liquidity for $6M

name: Umbrella Network
description: Hackers targeted Umbrella Network’s reward pools, and the incident resulted in $700k being drained from both BNB Chain and Ethereum.

name: Li.finance
description: According to official reports, attackers exploited Li.finance’s smart contracts and managed to steal around $600k

name: OneRing Finance
description: Stablecoin revenue optimizer OneRing issued a document saying that hackers stole 1,454,672 USDC through flash loan attacks.

name: Arthur
description: Arthur's hot wallet was suspected of having been stolen.

name: REALSWAK
description: The NFT project REALSWAK has a Rug Pull, scammers have transferred over $537k.

name: Cashio
description: Cashio was attacked today and lost $28 million to the attackers, with the price of its native token crashing to zero.

name: InuSaitama
description: InuSaitama suffered from an arbitrage attack and lost over $1M

name: Revest Finance
description: DeFi protocol Revest Finance has been hacked and lost around $2M in ETH tokens

name: BuccaneerFi
description: BuccaneerFi rug pulled and stolen over $360k

name: Ronin
description: The Ronin bridge and Katana Dex have been halted after suffering an exploit for 173,600 Ethereum (ETH) and 25.5 million USD Coin (USDC), worth a combined $650 million

name: BNBDEFI
description: BNBDEFI rug pulled its users and ran with $110k

name: BMIZapper
description: There was a vulnerability in BMIZapper, which caused users to lose about 1.2 million US dollars.

name: Ola Finance
description: Ola Finance on the Fuse chain published a blog post on the hacking incident, stating that the attack lost approximately $4.67 M

name: Inverse Finance
description: Inverse Finance lost over $15.6M due to the hackers' attack

name: Agora (StarStream)
description: The attacker borrowed approximately $8.2 million worth of tokens from Agora.

name: CF
description: The CF token contract was fundamentally flawed by allowing anyone to drain others' CF balance. So far, the loss is about $1.9M

name: Marvin Inu
description: Marvin Inu’s cross-chain bridge was hacked, and tokens worth $352k

name: Elephant Money
description: The official loss from this exploit is 27,416 BNB, valued at $11.2M at the time of writing.

name: Rikkei Finance
description: DeFi protocol Rikkei Finance was attacked because the attacker changed the oracle machine to a malicious contract. The total loss value is approximately $1.1 million.

name: Beanstalk
description: Beanstalk Farms, an Ethereum-based stablecoin protocol, was exploited for $182 million

name: Zeed
description: The DeFi ecological protocol ZEED was attacked and lost about $1M.

name: MaxAPYFinance
description: MaxAPYFinance rugged its users for $440k

name: Akutars
description: Due to the breach the hacker managed to lock over $34M on the contract

name: Deus Finance
description: Fantom-based decentralized derivatives protocol DEUS Finance was attacked, and the hackers made about $13.4M in profit.

name: Rari Capital
description: Rari Capital lost over $80M in ETH due to a hackers attack

name: Saddle Finance
description: DeFi protocol Saddle Finance was attacked, causing the protocol to lose more than $10 million.

name: MM.finance
description: MM.finance site was the subject of a DNS attack earlier where an attacker managed to inject a malicious contract address into the frontend code.

name: Mining Capital Coin
description: Mining Capital Coin CEO charged with $62M crypto fraud

name: Pragma Money
description: Pragma rug pulled its customers and took over $1.5M

name: Day of Defeat
description: Day of Defeat rug pulled its customers and took over $1.3M

name: Fury of the Fur
description: NFTproject Fury of the Fur rug pulled its customers with over $300k

name: Hunter
description: The DeFi project Hunter has been rug pulled with over $1.2M of illegal profit

name: Fortress
description: Fortress has been hacked and lost over $3M

name: GOAT
description: Goat rug pulled its customers and took over $260k

name: Cashera
description: A rug pull has occurred on project Cashera, and $90k USD was taken.

name: ownlyio
description: The ownlyio project's NFTStaking contract was attacked, with a loss of about $36k

name: x2y2
description: Using an exploit with Google ads, scammers are able to make the real and scam URL look exactly the same.

name: Quickswap
description: Decentralized exchange Quickswap has come under attack for a vulnerability in its hosting provider GoDaddy.

name: FEG
description: The multi-chain DeFi protocol FEG was suspected of being attacked, and a total of 143 Ethereum and 32,747 BNB were lost, about $1.3 million.

name: FEG
description: FEG lost an additional $600k in a hackers attack

name: Feminist Metaverse
description: The Feminist Metaverse project on BNB Chain was attacked. The attackers have transferred 1838 BNB to Tornado.cash, about $540,000.

name: QANplatform
description: QANplatform was attacked on both Ethereum and BNBChain and lost over $630k

name: Llamascape
description: Llamascape's NFT collection was hacked. The hackers targeted their Discord server, and around $100k was taken by the scammers.

name: bDollar
description: The first algorithmic stablecoin project on Binance Smart Chain, bDollar, suffered a price manipulation attack, and the attacker made a profit of about $730k.

name: DecentraWorld
description: DecentraWorld's DEWO token price plummeted, and the founding team of DecentraWorld drained the project's funds and stole about $1 million

name: Mirror Protocol
description: Terra research forum member FatMan tweeted that the Mirror Protocol, a synthetic asset protocol developed by Terraform Labs, has a longstanding vulnerability. Since October 2021, attackers have exploited this vulnerability for multiple attacks within a period of 7 months, and the highest single profit exceeded $4 million.

name: PokeMoney
description: PokeMoney blockchain game rug pulls for $3.5 million

name: Anchor Protocol
description: Hacker got a "free" $800k thanks to the bug that happened on Anchor Protocol lending and borrowing platform

name: Novo
description: Novo suffered an exploit in the amount of $90k

name: Mirror Protocol
description: Mirror Protocol suffered from the new exploit and lost around $2M

name: Armadillo Coin
description: Rug Pull on Armadillo Coin on BNB Chian, scammers have transferred $265k

name: Animoon
description: The work of Animoon with 9999 NFTs is taken from Pokémon. They claim to have signed a non-disclosure agreement (NDA) with Pokémon partner TopDeck. But with no evidence of an actual P2E game being developed, the Animoon team disappeared, deleting their Twitter account and website.

name: CoFiXProtocol
description: The project CoFiXProtocol on BNB Chian suffered a price manipulation attack, and the attackers made a profit of about $140k

name: BAYC&Otherside
description: Discord account of NFT projects was breached, which let the scammers execute their phishing attacks. Over $250k was stolen.

name: fomo-dao
description: The fomo-dao project was attacked, and the attacker has made a profit of $110k

name: Maiar Exchange (Elrond)
description: Maiar DEX Loses $113 Million Worth of EGLD because of having a security breach

name: Osmosis
description: Osmosis, a decentralized exchange built on Cosmos, was hacked for roughly $5M.

name: Gym Network
description: GYM NETWORK was hacked and lost $2.1M

name: ApolloX
description: The ApolloX project was attacked due to a flaw in the ApolloX signature system. Hacker managed to drain over $1.6M

name: BabyElon
description: BabyElon rug pulls for $180k

name: Optimism
description: Optimism lost over $15M in the hackers attack

name: Treasure Swap
description: The Treasure Swap attacker has completed the attack on the two contracts and accumulated a profit of 3,945 BNB.

name: SHELL
description: Shell rug pulls for $180k

name: Hege Token
description: HEGE token rug pulled its customers for approximately $429,000.

name: Fswap
description: Fswap lost around $500k due to hackers' attack

name: ElonMVP
description: The ElonMVP token suffered from a Rug Pull and took over $130k

name: Inverse Finance
description: Inverse Finance suffered a flash loan attack, resulting in a loss of approximately 1068.215 ETH (approximately $1.26 million).

name: LV PLUS
description: The LV PLUS (Token LVP) project has been identified as a Rug Pull project. So far, the project has resulted in losses of about $1.5 million.

name: DHE
description: A Rug Pull occurred in the DHE project, total losses are currently around $142k.

name: Harmony
description: The Horizon Bridge to the Harmony layer-1 blockchain has been exploited for $100 million in altcoins which are being swapped for Ether.

name: Ribbon Finance
description: Ribon Finance lost over $330k because of the security breach

name: ConvexFinance
description: ConvexFinance officially tweeted that a DNS attack caused users to approve malicious contracts on some interactions on the website

name: xCarnival
description: The NFT liquidity solver XCarnival was attacked, the hacker made a profit of 3,087 ETH (about 3.8 million US dollars)

name: Quint
description: Quint was hacked for about $130k

name: Mad
description: Mad was hacked in the amount of $115k

name: Crema Finance
description: The centralized liquidity DeFi application Crema Finance on the Solana chain announced its shutdown due to a hacker attack.

name: BiFi
description: BIFROST officially released a report saying that the BTC address registration server of the BiFi service was attacked.

name: Omni X
description: Decentralized NFT financialization protocol Omni X has been attacked and lost over $1.5M
